Award.AwardTitle: Metabolomics: Development of novel metabolic analysis system for 1-butanol production

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Biological engineering offers great promise for the production of next generation biofuels that are a sustainable alternative to fossil fuels. This research project will use novel high-throughput technologies to understand how microorganisms, such as baker's yeast and photosynthetic bacteria, produce these fuel molecules as part of their natural metabolism. Just as advances in DNA sequencing technology have made it possible to read whole genomes, new methods allow scientists to measure the metabolome, all the chemicals produced by the cell's metabolism. This project will combine a deep understanding of the genes and the chemical processes inside the cell and use novel computer modeling approaches to guide genetic engineering approaches that will boost the production of butanol, an advanced biofuel.

Broader Impacts
This project will integrate advanced training opportunities for young scientists in both the US and Japan through collaboration between the University of California, Los Angeles, Osaka University, Kobe University, and the Kaiteki Institute of the Mitsubishi Chemical Company in Japan. The training of students and postdoctoral fellows will be enriched through an exchange program between the participating laboratories, and by participation in an international workshop on the new technologies being developed in this project. A goal of this project is to train the next generation of researchers in the field of environmentally-conscious biofuels.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The increasing atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO2) level has become a major concern for the world. While deep de-carbonization is a necessary direction to alleviate the problem, it may not be realized fast enough to curtail the CO2 level to an acceptable range. In addition, chemical carbon capture faces a storage problem. Therefore, it is desirable to directly or indirectly convert CO2 to chemicals or fuels.  To do so, biological systems provide the most promise, as photosynthesis has the best activity to absorb CO2 from the atmosphere and convert it to biomass. The biomass produced can then be converted to sugar, which is then used by microorganisms to produce chemicals and fuel. To do so, one has to genetically engineer microorganisms to allow the cell to synthesize the chemicals of interest.   However, engineering microorganisms to achieve an un-natural task is challenging, and typically involves multi-years of trials and errors. Therefore, it is desirable to develop new tools to accelerate such a development process.

The goal of this project is to develop modern biology and engineering tools for constructing bacterial strains to produce chemicals or fuels.  Our target products include butanol and 3-hydroxypurvate, which can be used as an industrial chemical or biofuel. We engineer E. coli and cyanobacteria to convert glucose or CO2, respectively, into these chemicals. To do so, we develop engineering modeling techniques to guide the design of metabolic systems. We also developed advanced metabolomics techniques which allowed us to measure most, if not all, the chemicals inside the cells. In addition, we combine genome editing, directed evolution, and proteomics to achieve our goals. We successfully developed an E. coli strain that can produce 1-butanol from glucose in salt solutions without any expensive nutrients.  We also developed a cyanobacteria strain that can produce 1-butanol from CO2 directly.
